justification: “The IUS-12 is a 12-item scale that assesses intolerance of uncertainty.”
“Researchers commonly use the Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale to assess intolerance of uncertainty … A 27-item version (IUS-27) and a shorter 12-item version exist.”

measured_by: Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale – 12-item Healthcare version (IUS-12-H)
justification: “To create the IUS-12-H, we took the IUS-12 items and adapted them to a medical context… The IUS-12-H will now permit the measurement of IU among HCPs.”
construct: Intolerance of uncertainty in healthcare practice

justification: “According to Sandid (2016), the scale assesses four aspects of uncertainty: anxiety about uncertainty, worry about adverse events, reluctance to disclose uncertainty to patients, and reluctance to disclose medical errors to other physicians.”
“The scale measures four lower-order factors … and one higher-order factor (‘General distress tolerance’).”
“The scale assesses two lower-order factors … and one higher-order factor (‘General discomfort intolerance’).”
“This scale estimates the amount of stress perceived by the respondent over the last two weeks.”

measured_by: Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale – 16 item (DERS-16)

justification: “Questionnaire … measures the perceived uncertainty in the professional environment.”
construct: Perceived uncertainty in the professional environment

justification: “This scale measures the extent to which a person enjoys engaging in higher cognitive activities.”
“This scale measures the cognitive need to arrive at an answer, an end regarding a subject.”

measured_by: Tolerance of Ambiguity in Medical Students and Doctors scale (TAMSAD)
justification: “This scale assesses intolerance to ambiguity (IA), a construct close to but different from intolerance to uncertainty (IU).”
